title: Sydney industrial yields dip below 5 per cent as values surge
text:
Asking rents increased by a more modest 2.6 per cent to $155 per sq m, but are still the highest in the country by a significant margin, while incentives were unchanged at a low 9 per cent.

Colliers said Sydney had reported an increase in industrial land values in the range of 85-215 per cent for the past five years while Melbourne’s land values had increased 25-105 per cent and Brisbane’s 25-50 per cent over the same period.

“As more than half of the Australian population remains heavily concentrated in Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane, industrial land values in these capital cities will continue to trend upwards, with the transition from bricks-and-mortar retail to e-commerce retail becoming another key driver of industrial activity in these regions," said Karina Salas, research manager at Colliers International.

Malcolm Tyson, the firm's managing director of industrial, said $133 billion committed to transport projects on the east coast – 65 per cent of which are due to be completed in the next three to five years – was another big factor in rising land values.

“There can be no doubt that the current transport infrastructure investment is set to transform the outlook of the industrial market for operators, developers and investors alike," he said.

While land values have been rising across the east coast, other capital city markets look cheap by comparison to Sydney.

Land values in Melbourne, where average yields tightened by 30 basis points to 5.73 per cent, were unchanged in the September quarter at $393 per sq m, while values rose slightly in Brisbane to $321 per sq m and to $205 per sq m in Adelaide.

Perth land values were unchanged at $438 per sq m, as were rents at $79 per sq m (with incentives at a high 17.5 per cent).
description: Average industrial yields in Sydney tightened to 4.75 per cent in the third quarter of 2019, down from 5.04 per cent six months ago.
